docs.snippet: Coming into tonight's World Boxing Council welterweight title fight, the champion, Pernell Whitaker, said he was concerned that the undefeated but unheralded challenger, Diobelis Hurtado, might not make it out of the dressing room.    ''When he re...
docs.lead_paragraph: Coming into tonight's World Boxing Council welterweight title fight, the champion, Pernell Whitaker, said he was concerned that the undefeated but unheralded challenger, Diobelis Hurtado, might not make it out of the dressing room. ''When he realizes that he is fighting the best pound-for-pound fighter in the world, he might faint,'' said Whitaker, who did not bother to watch Hurtado on tape.
docs.abstract: Pernell Whitaker knocks out challenger Diobelis Hurtado in 11th round of 12-round bout for World Boxing Council welterweight title at Atlantic City Convention Center, NJ (M)

headline.main: Whitaker, Knocked Down, Comes Back to Knock Out Challenger

docs.snippet: The death of a 43-year-old woman rehearsing a bungee jumping routine Thursday night at the Superdome for Sunday's Super Bowl halftime show raised questions here today about the extravagant and often risky entertainment productions that have become...
docs.lead_paragraph: The death of a 43-year-old woman rehearsing a bungee jumping routine Thursday night at the Superdome for Sunday's Super Bowl halftime show raised questions here today about the extravagant and often risky entertainment productions that have become commonplace at large sporting events. Laura Patterson, a 43-year-old aerialist from Sarasota, Fla., died from injuries she sustained from striking her head on the Superdome floor while practicing a jump that she was to perform during the final 30 seconds of the planned 12-minute halftime show. Patterson was part of a 16-member bungee jumping act. Her husband, Scott Osgood, and her sister, Wendy, were part of the act and were among the more than 700 performers at the practice.
docs.abstract: Death of woman rehearsing bungee jumping routine at Superdome for Super Bowl half-time show raises questions about extravagant and often risky entertainment productions that have become commonplace at large sporting events; National Football League Comr Paul Tagliabue says bungee jumping act will be eliminated from show and woman's death will be noted in some way; woman, Laura Patterson, was 43-year-old aerialist; photos (M)

headline.main: Superdome Death Stirs Questions on Risks of Shows

docs.snippet: It sometimes seems that the French are going to end up like some indigenous tribe studied by future cultural anthropologists for their odd dress. Today's French resistance is against revolutions in fashion occurring elsewhere, made more glaring th...
docs.lead_paragraph: It sometimes seems that the French are going to end up like some indigenous tribe studied by future cultural anthropologists for their odd dress. Today's French resistance is against revolutions in fashion occurring elsewhere, made more glaring this season by John Galliano's updating of the greatest French standard of them all, Christian Dior. There is a sort of Zen peacefulness in the intractability. That is what has defined Yves Saint Laurent for several years, and it is difficult not to be lulled by the voice of couture, which calls off each numbered gown at the house's show.
docs.abstract: Amy M Spindler reviews Paris couture shows; photos (M)

docs.snippet: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions in Manhattan that are to close soon:    Closing This Weekend    ''AN IDEAL HUSBAND,'' Barrymore Theater, 243 West 47th Street. The Oscar Wilde comedy; with Michael Allinson, Nicky Henson, Stephanie Beach...
docs.lead_paragraph: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions in Manhattan that are to close soon: Closing This Weekend ''AN IDEAL HUSBAND,'' Barrymore Theater, 243 West 47th Street. The Oscar Wilde comedy; with Michael Allinson, Nicky Henson, Stephanie Beacham, Madeleine Potter, James Warwick and Kim Hunter; directed by Peter Hall. Through Sunday. Performances: Today at 8 P.M.; tomorrow at 2 and 8 P.M.; Sunday at 3 P.M. Tickets: $32.50 to $60. Information: (212) 239-6200. ''THE TWO GENTLEMEN OF VERONA,'' New Victory Theater, 209 West 42d Street. The Shakespeare comedy, presented by the International Shakespeare Globe Center and the Theater for a New Audience. Through tomorrow. Performances: Tonight at 7; tomorrow at 2 and 7 P.M. Tickets: $10 to $25. Information: (212) 239-6200.
docs.abstract: List of some shows and exhibits set to close in New York

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    In his Jan. 21 letter assailing the film director Elia Kazan's politics during the Red Scare era, Theo Zimmerman bemoans the missed opportunities in the career of the blacklisted director Jules Dassin. Actually, for Mr. Dassin th...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In his Jan. 21 letter assailing the film director Elia Kazan's politics during the Red Scare era, Theo Zimmerman bemoans the missed opportunities in the career of the blacklisted director Jules Dassin. Actually, for Mr. Dassin the blacklist was a strange blessing in disguise.
docs.abstract: Phil Hall reply to Theo Zimmerman's Jan 21 letter on director Elia Kazan (S)

docs.snippet: With OSCAR DE LA HOYA waiting in the wings for a big payday in April, PERNELL WHITAKER might be expected to take DIOBELIS HURTADO lightly for their World Boxing Council welterweight title fight at the Atlantic City Convention Center tomorrow night...
docs.lead_paragraph: With OSCAR DE LA HOYA waiting in the wings for a big payday in April, PERNELL WHITAKER might be expected to take DIOBELIS HURTADO lightly for their World Boxing Council welterweight title fight at the Atlantic City Convention Center tomorrow night. But Whitaker, who started out as a lightweight, concedes that he learned a valuable lesson in the first of his two, and only, fights last year against WILFREDO RIVERA. Admittedly unmotivated and unprepared for that bout last April in the Netherland Antilles, Whitaker was lucky to emerge with a split-decision victory.
docs.abstract: World Boxing Council welterweight champion Pernell Whitaker will fight Diobelis Hurtado in Atlantic City on Jan 24 (S)

headline.main: For Whitaker, It's Time to Focus

docs.snippet: They may be ugly, blind and foul, but they're among the major attractions at the 1997 Sundance Film Festival. And when hairless pink mole rats start looking like movie stars, it's proof that Park City is witnessing Bizarro Sundance this year.     ...
docs.lead_paragraph: They may be ugly, blind and foul, but they're among the major attractions at the 1997 Sundance Film Festival. And when hairless pink mole rats start looking like movie stars, it's proof that Park City is witnessing Bizarro Sundance this year. This festival, the pre-eminent showcase for American independent film, hit its high-water mark last year with a phenomenal array of appealing, accessible features (among them ''Big Night,'' ''Welcome to the Dollhouse,'' ''Looking for Richard,'' ''Walking and Talking,'' ''The Whole Wide World'' and ''Citizen Ruth''). And Sundance is sure to be represented on Oscar night, not only by ''Shine,'' last year's smash hit, but by ''Jerry Maguire,'' which has the sweet, quirky spirit that so often prevails here.
docs.abstract: Janet Maslin on offerings at 1997 Sundance Film Festival; photos (M)

docs.snippet: Microsoft is a corporate behemoth with 20,000 workers famous for their Dockers office wear and their cool rationality, whether analyzing a line of computer code or a marketing plan.     Silicon Alley is the name given to the confluence of hundreds...
docs.lead_paragraph: Microsoft is a corporate behemoth with 20,000 workers famous for their Dockers office wear and their cool rationality, whether analyzing a line of computer code or a marketing plan. Silicon Alley is the name given to the confluence of hundreds of small companies staffed by creative young people drawn to New York City. In Manhattan lofts where once they might have formed little magazines or rock-and-roll bands, today they are putting up Web sites.
docs.abstract: Microsoft, with eye on huge potential of Internet, is currently involved in search for original programming from digital entrepreneurs in New York City; these entrepreneurs, most residing in lower Manhattan, create everything from interactive soap operas to on-line magazines (M)

headline.main: Microsoft Goes to Manhattan in Search of Countercultural Cool

docs.snippet: It would seem hard to lose a three-balcony opera house, with room for 3,000 people under its broad dome, that was built in 1906 by the flamboyant impresario Oscar Hammerstein and once gave the Met a run for its money.    Then again, this is a big ...
docs.lead_paragraph: It would seem hard to lose a three-balcony opera house, with room for 3,000 people under its broad dome, that was built in 1906 by the flamboyant impresario Oscar Hammerstein and once gave the Met a run for its money. Then again, this is a big city with a short memory.
docs.abstract: Article discusses refurbishing of Manhattan Opera House, three-balcony opera house with room for 3,000 people under its broad dome, that was built in 1906 by flamboyant impresario Oscar Hammerstein; photo (M)

headline.main: A Hammerstein Theater, No Phantom, Is Reborn

docs.snippet: Col. Tom Parker, the strict, unorthodox and controversial manager who orchestrated Elvis Presley's career from 1955 until the singer's death in 1977, died yesterday at Valley Hospital in Las Vegas, Nev. He was 87.    The cause was complications fr...
docs.lead_paragraph: Col. Tom Parker, the strict, unorthodox and controversial manager who orchestrated Elvis Presley's career from 1955 until the singer's death in 1977, died yesterday at Valley Hospital in Las Vegas, Nev. He was 87. The cause was complications from a stroke, said Bruce Banke, a longtime friend and a former executive at the Las Vegas Hilton.
docs.abstract: Col Tom Parker, strict, unorthodox and controversial manager who orchestrated Elvis Presley's career from 1955 until singer's death in 1977, dies at age 87; photo (M)

headline.main: Tom Parker Is Dead at 87; Controlled Presley's Career
